awd_titl_txt: CONFERENCE: Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Synthetic Biology Course-July 27-August 10, 2015
awd_abstract_narration:
Synthetic biology is a rapidly expanding multi-disciplinary research area that relies on the integration of expertise in biology, engineering, mathematics, chemistry, and physics. This field uses theoretical and engineering principles to advance fundamental biological understanding and develop bio-inspired products. The challenge of synthetic biology today is that interdisciplinary expertise is often minimal, whereas a basic comprehension of the various underlying fields is crucial to foster successful collaborations. This course (July 27 - August 10, 2015) offered through the Cold Spring Harbor summer course educational program  represents a significant effort to address this need. The series of lectures include laboratory exposure to cutting edge advances in experimental and theoretical synthetic biology. The course is structured to motivate the participants to share their knowledge with colleagues at their home institutions, which may inspire more broadly a systems and synthetic biology course and curriculum development. This course will help advance an emerging interdisciplinary science that, in addition to providing insights into the complexity of biology, will also inspire innovations that can provide critical solutions for many current and impending societal needs. 

The course fulfills an important need for development of an interdisciplinary research workforce that is more aware of the opportunities that can be realized from interdisciplinary collaborations including effective communication between students and experts. The teaching material includes cutting edge training in such areas as the theory and use of CRISPR technology to alter the genome of complex biological systems; proficiency in cell-free transcription-translation (TX-TL) methods; rapid molecular cloning using the Golden Gate assembly method; and gaining fundamental understanding of computational biology using ordinary differential equations. In addition, the course will provide sessions to develop specific biosensors for metabolic engineering.

por.por_cntn:
The CSHL Synthetic Biology summer course provided participants with intense instruction on the latest computational and experimental approaches to dissect fundamental and application-specific problems at the leading edge of synthetic biology. The course had three parts: a hands-on laboratory basic training component to bestow students with practical skills in computational and experimental methodologies; an intensive research-oriented project component where students applied their practical training to active research from the instructors’ laboratories; and a seminar series where leading synthetic biology experts presented their work, novel methods, and tools developed in their labs. The program:

a)   provided the opportunity for established biologists, physicists, mathematicians, computer scientists and other experts unfamiliar with synthetic biology to learn the state-of-the art in the field of synthetic biology;

b)   provided the opportunity for industry practitioners to gain exposure to the wide array of theory and practice in synthetic biology so that they may apply this knowledge in their products and pipelines;

c)   provided faculty with advanced practical experiences that will be useful in their courses and/or laboratories;

d)  helped the instructors themselves develop into the next generation of synthetic biology leaders;

e) provided outstanding graduate students and postdoctoral fellows with an opportunity to work, study, and network with experts in synthetic biology; and

f)  facilitated interdisciplinary research and collaborations by bringing together a diverse group of research workers from each of the STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) fields.

In summary, the CSHL summer courses on Synthetic Biology provided an intensive two-week immersion into cutting-edge synthetic biology methods, helping to prepare the next generation of synthetic biologists to work at the interface of biological, computational, and physical sciences.
